text: Bottle. Aroma is yeasty dough with malt. Appearance is hazy gold with excellent sparkle and 1/2 finger-width, frothy white head with moderate foamy lacing. Taste is medium sweet with notes of citrus. Palate is light to medium bodied with creamy texture, subtle carbonation supporting the beer and mildly buzzing the edges of the tongue and tip. Finish is abrupt, dry and minimally bitter. Overall, this beer has nice features with different tastes/aromas, attractive presentation and pleasing palate.

Bottle at my parents. I grabbed this haphazardly while filling out mix 6. Dusty golden in color almost no head. Nose is faint malt and grass. Tastes of grass, touch of herbs, wheat, basement, wild flowers. Crisp enough
Draft at dinosaur BBQ in Stamford. Light tan color. No head. Easy drinking not as malty dark as I wanted
hazy gold, large bubbled white head. dusty corn nose. Dryer flavor, grain bitterness with slight bubblegum sweetness. Thin, light carbonation, empty corn grain finish. Meh.
GCB: Not my beer stylistically. But good if your in the fall mood. A good beer for what they were shooting for.

Bottle shared by Travlr via the Somalia desk guy. Pours clear gold with a small, frothy white head, short retention with spare lacing. Aroma is Pils malt and light spicy hops. Flavor is malt dominant with light hops and bitterness with a dry finish. Light body and medium carbonation.
Thanks to Travlr, thanks Gene! Poured a clear light yellow color with an almost non existent white head. Aroma was malts, toasted notes. Flavor was malty, sweet notes. Drinkable.

Pours a light golden color with white foamy head. Aroma is grassy and malty. Taste is grainy and slightly tart with a nice clean finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

355mL thanks to Travlr. Low haze light orange pour. Weaker white foam. Spotty lace. Nose is mild candies, toffee, grass, hay, moldy grain, rustic. Taste is a bit bland, suddy, weak with not a lot of malt presence. Watery, suddy body.
Bottle courtesy of Adam of Somalia, thanks!  Murky orange amber color, small white edge head. Aroma of dirty, earthy straw. Taste is bitter straw.  Plain.

Verre de dégustation, provenant dune bouteille de 12 oz, au Mondial de la Bière 2012 (Montréal, QC). Arôme: Légère odeur de céréales avec une pointe de noix. Apparence: La couleur est blonde pâle. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Léger goût de céréales et dhoublons. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de céréales en arrière goût. (Rating #4394)

A blonde lager with a thin white head. In aroma, a light chalky malt with faint herbal hops. In mouth, a crisp clean sweet malt with grassy hops and mineral notes. Bottle at Mondial 2012, June 10 2012.
One of Hookers  better offerings. Light in three glass, crisp in three mouth with a good hours bite, a solid undertone of wheat in the body to lingers into the finish after the hops have faded.

After a recent visit from the Thomas Hooker representative, I wanted to try the full variety of brews.  Ive had most (if not all) of the Hooker beers over the past couple years, after all they are practically right down the road.  Theres also a few rumors floating that some new beers are on the way, so revisiting the old favorites is becoming even more of a priority.

This brew from Hooker Brewing is the Munich Style Lager.  There is often a shortage of Lagers among craft brewers, largely because of the extended brewing time compared to that of Pale Ales and IPAs. This Munich Style Lager is cool-fermented and aged for 6 weeks, compared to the average ale which can be ready in just 2-3 weeks.

Munich Style Lager pours out a clear golden color, with just a thin layer of white foam. The head fades back pretty quickly, as you can see by my 3-seconds too late photo.  The aromas are what I think of as the quintessential smell of beer.  Just a touch of hops is largely overwhelmed by the firm backbone of malts. This isnt the candy-sweet style of malty aromas though, Im talking about the just slightly sweet, bready/grainy style of hops.  It smells much like the best lagers in the business, such as Augustiner and Weihenstephaner.

On the palate, this Lager is almost exactly what I expected: crisp, clean, and easy-drinking. Theres a touch of malty sweetness up front, which just a slightly dry finish on the back-side. A deliciously balanced brew! I now know why this Munich Style Lager is ranked so highly on beerAdvocate!  Why did I not try this one sooner? 

Located in Bloomfield, CT, Thomas Hooker brewing has received some serious accolades over the past 10+ years that theyve been brewing.  High on the "best brewery" lists from both beerAdvocate and RateBeer, this local favorite should not be over-looked!
12oz bottle in a lager glass.  Pours golden with a thick, off-white head.  Aroma of pale malts with a little bit of nuts, plus light hops.  Flavor the same.  Light texture.  A decent beer.
Middle of the road. A fine beer abit boring. Medium bodied. Typical look & feel.

Bottle.  Possibly an old one at that.  Pours a hazed amber orange with a thin white head.  Somewhat of a soured apple note, old fruit, oxidization and paper.  Medium bodied, full of oxidized paper, slightly vegetal with cabbage notes.  Not so tasty.  Finishes with more old malt, oxidized vegetables.  Not so good.  Might have been a nice crisp helles at one point, but those days are long gone for this bottle.

I had this for the first time last summer as part of a limited edition offering.  I was thrilled to see it back this summer.  Its got a light straw color and a bready, slightly sour taste (but in a very pleasing way).  It almost tastes lightly of lemon.

This is the best lager Ive ever had.  Im looking forward to trying more Munich style lagers to see if there are indeed lagers out there that have flavor to them.  What a concept!

12 oz bottle into a sam adams perfect pint. Born on date of 3/22/2011.

A - Dark straw yellow body. Small soapy head.

S - Sweet bready malts. Just a dash of spice and hops.

T - Crisp and bready. Sweet and malty. Really easy drinking and refreshing. 

O - Nice lager. Has a good amount of flavor without being too complex or challenging. Seems like a really solid summer session beer.

On tap at bmannings wedding rehearsal dinner. Served in a beer boot, courtesy of bmanning. Thanks, Ben!

Pour yields a good white head of foam and some spotty lacing on the way down. The nose brings a nice subtle noble hoppiness plus light grain and a bit of bread. Excellent balance between all the components. The flavor is very nice as well with a good lightly-sweetened malt presence and a good level of hop flavor and bitterness to cut through the malt character. Light body and really crisp. Great dry finish and a high amount of carbonation. Really, really solid beer. Thomas Hooker seriously knows how to make lagers. Great way to say cheers.

Serving type: on-tap
Holy hell what the fuck?  Smells like an average clear beer.  The flavor? Horrid.  Maybe my bottle is bad?  Garbage flavor with some rotten lemons.  Fuck.

not sure if this was a bad one or not to be rated so highly, but it seemed to be overwhelmingly macro, macro aroma, palate, color, taste, etc. overly sweet malts combined with over carbonation makes this a miss.

Draught at TJs:  Aroma of lager yeast, pale malt, and noble hops.  Poured yellow/gold in color with a small, white head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Slightly hazy.  Not sparkling.  Good lacing.  Flavor is slightly sweet and light to medium bitter.  Tastes of Lager yeast, noble hops, pale malt, light grass, and grains.  Medium body.  Lightly dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Pale malt, noble hops, and light grass finish is dry.

A very smooth, drinkable, session beer. It has an earthy flavor to it, with a bread-like malty flavor and a light hop balance. An excellent seasonal offering: very refreshing, but at the same time having more flavor than most summer beers (Im looking at you, Sam Adams!)

(br-btl bu-lbl flp-top, 500ml, ¢34/oz, 5.3%)

strw-lct, thick foamy head and lace, ^eff, light body, ^co2.

aroma:  §alchl fresh fruity green-earthy.

flavor:  co2 T1, ^vinyl §bitter §iron T2, buttery-(diacetyl) bitter-hop-oil T3, actually-better bready fresh-hops §light-struck Tf.
Bottle.  Pours  a golden body with a white head.  Fruity and grain y dry with some yeast y notes, pepper and grains.  Bread y note with an earth y finish.

Pours a hazy gold with standard white head. Aroma is a bit offensive: yeast and a hint of ammonia. Did I get a bad batch? Oddly enough, only the aroma seems compromised. Flavor is inoffensive; fairly subtle hints of hops and some sweet malt. Smooth finish. Subtle and simple overall.

On tap at The Brass Rail. Lightly hazed gold with a small head. Aroma and taste are both very close to authentic German versions. Malty and bready without being sweet, a light touch of noble hops. Very refreshing. Possibly the most impressive American attempt at the style.

Orange coloured body with no head at all and a slightly cloudy appearance. Aroma of alcohol, wheat, coriander seed and very strong orange peel (curacao). Light-bodied; Strong malty flavour with wheat and coriander seed very noticeable. Aftertaste follows with spice and a hop bitterness very nicely. Overall, a pretty good helles style beer with very good characteristics. Watch out for laying this one on its side, with the swing-top (at least my bottle), because it will start leaking!!! I sampled this 500 mL bottle purchased at K&E Discount Beverages in New Paltz, New York on 28-October-2006.
(Bottle).  Flowery hay and grass aroma.  Light golden with large white head that laces well.   Flavor is a tad on the sweet side, but certainly smooth and refreshing.   Finish is a little sour.
very little aroma with a hint of sweetness. color of a bar gold with a slight light brown dark yellow tint. little head. very good beer if you wish to drink it as a session beer

5/08/2008:  Thomas Hooker Munich Style Golden Lager pours a hazy/cloudy yellow color with LOTS of fluffy and pillowy white head.  The aroma is light grainy with hints of toasted malt and some grassy hops and lemon-like tones coming through as well.  The flavor is malty (lighty sweet pale malt) with some nice yeasty bread and fruit qualities (some light citrus too) and balanced with some soft grassy and earthy hops.  Crisp and refreshing finish.  The body of this beer is medium-light to medium and is extremely smooth and easy on the palate.  I would say that this is a solid Helles beer that is especially sessionable.  I would drink this regularly if it were available to me.
500 ML flip-top bottle ($6.79) from Derosiers in Freeport, Maine.  Rating #74 for this beer...
Draft @ dba.  Yeah, not awful but not memorable. Poured a nice gold with not a ton of head. Taste of grass and other flavors. Mine was mildly skunky.
500ml flip top bottle. Poured a medium and lighlty hazy yellow color with an averaged sized white head. Aromas of yeast and lightly fruity. Tastes of fruitiness, yeast, and grains.

Grainy yeast aroma with a mild amount of tangy fruit. Cloudy orange-golden color with a small white head. No lacing to speak of. Initial light bitterness that fades on the way to the finish. Creamy palate.

Ths beer has a cluody color to it with no head at all. there is a faint aroma of malt and mild hops not very strong though. It has a initial flavor of nuts and mild earth flavors. The palate is very bland and kind of plain like a pale lager it is a little smooth like honey but not very sweet.

Not bad at all.  Malty but dry.  Toast and honey.  Very dry finish.  No hop bitterness perceived, but definitely a clean crispiness.  Im not getting an overt grassiness, but something is saying grass.  Maybe even a bit dusty, but in a pleasant way.  You really cant ask for much more in  a beer.  Its flavorful, complex and quite pleasant to drink.  The mouthfeel is wonderfully soft and smooth, almost soapy.  I love those toasty German malts in there as well.  The frightening thing is that this bottle is over a year old, so I think its safe to assume the beer could be even better fresh.  This is a style I wish more brewers would make, because it can be oh so very good.

500 mL swing-top acquired from porterhouse - thanks!  Sweet floral hops, vaguely Saazy but not really - well say central European for now.  Touch of bitter grain.  Clear golden pour with moderate carbonation and a rocky off-white / beige head.  Sweet floral taste, hops contributing laterally to the generous malt.  Touch of honey, lightly bitter and slightly crisp, medium-full with a spritz of orange rind and grain.  Quaffable, to be sure.  On the whole, well-crafted and pretty solid, but the citrus throws it off-style just a bit.

Pours bright gold into a shaker.  Bright white micro head subsides at a moderate pace to skim surface.  Clean aromas.  Crisp and full biscuit with a spicy middle that turns slightly sweet until the smooth resin hop finish.

Date: 08/04/2005
Mode: Bottle
Source: Ale Atlanta

dark yellow, sweet malt aroma, light sweet malt flavor, hint of hops, touch of bitterness in the finish

Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 4/10; Flavor: 2/10; Palate: 2/10; Overall: 5/20
Rating: 1.5/5.0Score: 4
-------- />
The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

(500 ml bottle from <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/maine/boothbay/ target=blank>1828 Vintage House) Pours hazy gold-amber with a tall off-white head. Aroma is kind of eggy with a sourish hint. Smooth, fairly full mouthfeel, yet finishes a little watery. Taste pretty much matches aroma with some eggy maltiness and sourish hints. Finish has a little hoppy bite. Frankly a bit of a letdown - the search for the great Dortmunder/Helles continues!

Very nicely done Helles, with the kind of pert, spicy nose that reminds you instantly of how satisfying this style can be. A nice pungent quality to the flavor, mixed in with crystal clear golden taste. Some nice malting, just a touch to balance, and a full body. Extremely good.

on cask at the spuyten duyvil, brooklyn.  cloudy, rusty yellow color, foamy white head.  aroma is italian bread crust, wet cigarettes, and pale malts.  flavor is a little dry/tart at te start, then pale malt and a little sweet caramel malt with a dry and grassy finish.  low carbonation since it is on cask.

Swingtop bottle via trade with Eyedrinkale! - Thanks Mike! - Pours blonde with a healthy white head that stays pretty well and laces some.  Aromas of almost all bread and grains.  Slight german hops do find their way through but not much.  Flavor is very much malt dominated too.  Good bready biscuit flavor throughout with some good german hallertau hops finishing this off.  Smooth throughout and easy drinking.  A pretty nice dortmunder here.

Tap. Pours with a golde color. Fairly robuts lager with aromas of predoimantly malts. Flavors of grain, malts and a strong hppy bitterness. Not really what I like in a lager, it was almost too powerful. I would not call that a really refreshing beer, certainly not much to do with a Dortmunder.
Draft.  Light golden color with a grainy aroma.  Light, biscuit and grain flavor.  Not bad, but I was hoping for better, even though its just a Helles.

Savannah, Ga. - Habersham Beverage Warehouse, 500 ml pop stop stubby bottle. Medium golden, cloudy pour with a fluffy white head that leaves thick lacing; good bubble action. Grassy aroma with hints of grain. Buttery flavor with some malty biscuity notes. Mouthfeel is decently thick, slightly creamy.

500 ml bottle. Pours a hazy medium gold with a moderate white head that kasted through the entire glass. Very pleasant aroma of apple cider and malt. The flavor is also malt with some sweetgrass and a bit of yeast as well. Light bitterness at the finish. Smooth on the palate and very easy to drink. This is my first beer from this brewer and I will definitely seek out other beers from them if this is an example of their work.
Bottle; wheaty malt nose; copper with a small white head; flavor of toasty bread and caramel out of the medium body witha dry finish.

Pours a nice jello orange color. Thick white head with a nice lacing on top of it.  Highly carbonated with a smooth malty, creamy taste. Smells spicy, and hoppy(Flowery). My least favorite from this brewery but all in all a good beer with some authentic german food.

500ml bottle from John (jjpm74) Thanks!  Pours out a brownish color with a nice white head.  Smell is hoppy and full of wheat and malts.  Taste is smooth and easy to drink.  Rich and creamy and downright pleasing and fun to drink.  Good stuff.

From a 22 oz. bomber with no freshness date.

Poured a hazy dull orangey golden with a slightly fluffy, foamy head that settled into a thin sudsy lacing.

Aromas of bread and a subtle grape, hints of toasted grain, softly spicy and herbal.

Good carbonation and malty crisp, dryish, creamy smooth light bodied mouthfeel.

Delicious Munich lager taste, light toasted barley and sweet bready caramel, a nice grape fruitiness, spicy, herbal hops that have a soft bitterness, and a dry grainy, biscuity finish.

An excellent lager, tasty and balanced, easy drinkability, for me, one of Thomas Hookers better offerings.

Courtesy of a fine Mystery Beer Swap participant. The aroma is a rich grainy thing that smells a bit like bread and wheat husks, but with a faintly dusty note. The body is bright gold and holds a fluffy, but mildly bubbly, white head. Grain accented fore is hearty and yet still light on the tongue. Tastes like a baked wheat cake with notes of barley and oats. That flavor gives it a thicker feel than the liquid itself possesses. Very light, mostly floral, hops with a slightly salty finish.
gold color under a large white head.  light hop but dominantly malty aroma.  bready malts and hint of hops in flavor.  good beer. light bodied.

Translucent golden-hued body, frothy white head.  Slightly honey-sweet aroma with just a hint of gentle hops.  Rich, malty body/flavor.  Surprisingly flavorful, and even a full mouthfeel.  A good idea of a dortmunder, and very easy to drink.

500ml swingtop - completely clear bright straw color, with substantial, but quick-fading head - lightly sweet aroma of honey and bread yeast, with some background grassy, herbal hops - medium-bodied and very smooth - quite earthy and floral - light buttery, bready flavors - very subtle honey flavor, with some mild fruity esters - some dry, mineral notes in the finish - a really solid lager.

Cask at d.b.a.  Hazy golden beer with a thick white head.  Arom ais fairly yeasty and earthy.  Bracing minerally notes.  Light citrus aroma, some light diacetyl as well.  Flavour is very minerally over a moderate noble hop flavour, earthy/dusty maltiness with lingering floral notes as well.  Pretty solid.
Aroma of bready sweetpils.  pale gold beer with snowcap frosting.  good pils flavor with honey malts.  mildly flavorful on the palate.  good "germanness" - delicious frothy creamy big head.

Tap. Pours a golden yellow, nice and clear  with some white foamy head. Aroma is a delicate blend of spice, hay and grass, and some grainy malt. Nice crips malt flavor with a touch of spiciness and light acidic hops. Highly drinkable.

22 oz bottle. Greens on Ponce.  Authentic Helles aroma, breadlike.  Light golden color, but not clear.  Has a hearty look to it witha thick white head.  Good lacing.  Flavor is different.  Toasted grain, maybe a wheat cracker.  Very well balanced. Medium bodied for a traditionally light style.  A good beer to share with friends just for something different.
On tap at the Connecticut Brew Fest. Clear gold with a thick, creamy white head. Bready nose, sweet biscuit. Sweet, malty biscuit flavor. Slightly flat body, but good overall.

22 oz bottle, pilsner glass.  A stunningly massive and creamy white head rests on an inspiring body that ranges from honey gold to pale straw in hue.  Pleasant and clean straw malts reach out and embrace sappy grass hop aromas.  A light honey sweetness pulls together with a firm, somewhat toasted, bready malts.  Delicate lemongrass and perfume tones fill the remaining spaces.  Honey and toasted bread malt notes play out fantastically in the flavor profile yeilding to a soft, grassy bitterness in the finish before taking reign once again in the aftertaste.  The mouthfeel is a little fuller than average but the real story is in the texture.   Its almost creamy, but plenty wet and slick enough to slide right off the tounge and leave you both satisfied and thirsting for another sip.  The carbonation is perhaps a <!-- i -->bit<!-- /i --> too much, but I could see it working just fine on a really hot day.  Id love to see what this would be like unfiltered, but thats life for you.  Seriously delicious.  Whod have thought Id regret not picking up a case of the pale lager (dort...but still) while I had the chance.  Frack.

Bobmer: Pours a nice amber oragne golden yellow color with some haze, almost like a dark hefe.  A thick fluffy head dissapates into a thin layer.  The aroma is of grass, lemon, honey, yeast, biscuts, dough, a touch of urine (but not in a gross way as strange as that sounds), and grapefruit.  The flavor is biscutty, grassy, a little malt, some almost raw grains/ingridients taste to it.

Great summer drink.  Deep golden color.  No alcohol info. but I would imagine it is in the 6-7 range.  Smells citrusy and malty.  Tastes like orange with a slight hint of bitterness almost like grapefruit.  Reminds me too much of pilsners.  Refreshing nonetheless.

Thanks to jjpm74 for this one.  The pour was a turbid orangy coppery, well carbonated presentation with a 1-finger creamy white head.  The aroma was of pale malt, honey, with a firm hopcitric element, specifically orange zest and apricots.  The taste was caramel malty and hopcitric with some tropical fruit and Florida citrus (orange, grapefruit) emerging as it warms.  More malty than hoppy, this one gains a bit of an APA profile as it warms.  Very nicely done.

bomber.  Pours a bit darker than many munich helles lagers, but is still pretty light almost a pure gold, dark straw color with a nice lasting head and lively carbonation.  Aroma is well balanced between bready pils malt and nice noble herbal and spicy hops.  Flavor is bready, pils malt, cracker like, smooth with a nice light bitter crisp finish.  Very well made american style helles.

Clear straw colored pour with a surprisingly lasting eggshell colored head.  Bready and malty nose.  Very light taste and body with more of the bread/bisquit as well as some yeast and light hopping.  Crisp finish. slightly bitter very clean.  Good summer beer.  May appeal to those who enjoy light beers like lagers or pilsners and I actually dig it considering I usually dont like lagers and the often associated corn taste.  Worth a try.

Sampled at the Milwaukee YEHa!05 courtesy of JPDIPSO: Pale clear golden pour has a thin ring of lightly-lacing white head.  Lightly sweet and slightly earthy saaz hop aroma.  Starts dry and very grainy with a thin, watery finish and a touch of bitterness.  Not very interesting, but drinkable I suppose.
Hazy golden amber body.  Whole-grain cracker aroma with a touch of husk.  Husky wheat cracker flavor with some corn notes.  Puckering mouthfeel.
A malty aroma with some noticeable grainy notes.  Pale, cloudy yellow with a thin white head.  Light malty, perfume flavor.  Very floral.  Watery, light body. Thanks to someone for sharing this.

Thanks to someone (?): Pours a dark golden color, small white head. Aroma is wheat, grains and other cereal such smells. Flavor is smooth, very easy to drink, no corn or any of that nonsense, clean crips flavor.

pours a hazy straw color w/ a tiny white head.  light sweet malt some straww pieces a bread dough and a tiny light melon.  Weak palate some ok coat and feel but very light.  Flavor is a light straw flavor and a bread dough and some light sweet.  Nothing special.

Pours to a bronzed hazy straw body with no head.  The aroma is exactly like what reminds me of cigar tobacco.  Am I on crack?  I love a good cigar.  The flavor is not very good, however.  Light yeasty, malty, cigar.  Aromatic hops.  The palate is medium bodied and decent.

Clear deep gold, tiny fading white head. Grainy, mainly malty nose that is highly toasted and slightly bready. Mild sourdoughyness develops midway betraying the quality of the malt extraction. Light grassiness emanate from the hop aromatics, accentuating the sense of balance without distracting from the overall mellow feel. Crisp medium body, efficient cleasing carbonation. Thanks Clark!

(22oz bottle) Lightly hazed apple juice body with big off-white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, cereal, apple, some floral, light orange.  Taste is medium sweet, cereal, some apple, biscuit, light floral.  Watery light body with limited crispness.

(22 oz bottle: Obtained in trade with ClarkVV, thanks Clark!) This is one hell of a golden lager!  Very bready, grainy, somewhat sweet, and gently bitter, with a light and very pleasant smokiness in the finish.  Despite being lightly bitter, there is a modest hoppiness lending some crispness to the palate.  Light-medium bodied, but more than substantial enough for the style.  The nose is bready and grainy, with a slight hoppiness in the background.  Medium golden in color and fairly cloudy in appearance, but the small white head settles to a filmy layer.  Overall a very pleasant beer in a bomber that has gone down entirely too easily and quickly.  One of the better beers Ive had in this style.

Clear golden pour with a thin white head. Good aroma of crisp malt and noble hops. The flavor is enjoyable, nice crisp malt and noble hops, it finishes bitter. The palate is smooth and creamy. Its good, very crisp and clean.

The Lure:Citrusy refreshment merging with the humble cereal. Earthy hops shyly approach the biscuity malts. Lactic sweetness dripping through the haystack.

The Festivities:Crisp cereal slowly forming a nourishing loaf of bread. A dry, hoppy finish intrigues the tongue enough the make it plunge back for another sip. Personally, I would have preferred a little more hop flavor, but as is this is a suitable quencher for both craft beer lovers and their thirsty acquantainces.

Transcendence:Simplicity can be appeasing.

Deep golden color with a tall ecru head and an even tatted sheet of lace. Fresh baked bread and cookie nose , with hints of lemon zest and brie. The yeast seem a touch strong in the aroma. Light sweet start with a light malt an herbal zip toward the middle. Clean and lightly fruity in the finish. Full mouth feel, but plenty of eff to lighten its journey. Quite traditional, but could use a touch more hops to to balance all the cookie dough.  Thanks to Andrew and John.

Pours nicely.  Fine lager aroms but rather non-descript.  On the palate nicely done.  Clean and crisp and drinkable.  Finsihes a bit sweet but strill in style.
Nice brew.
Bottle. Golden, clear, nice fluffy white head. Clean malty aroma. Light crisp clean malty flavors. Malty finish. Lots of pale malts. No off notes. Well done.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text:
I believe it was rater ClarkVV that sent me this Hooker! If I am incorrect please let me know! 

 Poured a beautiful golden body and a substantial cap of white froth lovely! The aroma and flavor are a cross between bitter & sweet Bread and Honey vs. Grassy, Mildly Citric Hops. The perfect battle! Cereal with peach slices. Crisp and dry in the finish. A Terrific Beer! It is SO Nice to see this style done well!

Bottle: Orangish gold, slight haze, large white foamy head, soft carbonation, spotty lacing. &nbsp Sweet malty nose, very subtle hop, honey, and cereal. &nbsp Sweet malt on the tongue, sweeter and quite heavier than other examples. &nbsp Moderate to full body and mouthfeel. &nbsp I must say, definitely heavier than other Helles. &nbsp Clean finish, quite sweet. &nbsp I really enjoyed this one. &nbsp Thanks John!

22 oz. bottle courtesy of my SecretSanta.  Orange pour with a thin, fizzy light-tan head.  Aroma is nicely balanced.  A little grainy.  A little grassy.  Some buttered white bread.  Smells like a quality lager.  Smooth, buttery, bready sweetness with enough hops in the finish to keep it balanced.  Hints of sourdough and corn.  Solid beer.  Boring style.

Bottle.  Light yellow gold pour.  Sweet malty aroma.  Sweet malty flavors, and maybe some lighter fruits.  Slight tartness too, probably from the Muinch malts.  Light bitter finish.  A drinkable to-style beer.  Just not quite my style.
Poured a slightly hazed yellow gold color with a thin white head.  Aroma of crisp apples and malt.  Flavor was sweet, malty, and fruity with a light bitter finish.
Clear gold body with a good head. Soft, lightly sweet with very low bitterness. Easy-drinking.

Bright clear yellow gold in color.  Aroma is nice and crisp, drawing out accents of honey, freshly baked croissants, a dash of coriander and flour sprinkled over baguettes.  Crisp, sweet and lemon flavored.  Some reminders of herbal butter over spread over crescent rolls, displaying a full and light breadyness.  Reaches all areas of the palate in a most delicate manner.  Gentle hop nature in agreement with a confident malt profile.  Light, fluffy bakery finish.  Well done.  Thanks to tpkenned for the bottle!

Sun driven gold with a small loosened white cap that crumbles at a steamy pace. Slow rising bubbles within tend to keep a light skim always present. Light stringy lace.

Soft aroma of sweet white bread grains and fresh doughy crusts. Slight grassy-like hopping.

Nice taster! Lovely sweet bready malts with a buttered corn crispness and tender grassy induced spice and mild bitterness. Pale malt finish with drying breadyness and lighter transference of dull caramel.

Gentle and firm well-rounded full-bodied, malt saturated feel. Tender carbonation; soft and chewyish. Solidly sweet with the white breads, but milded in tone enough for super extreme slopping down of this liquid. Nice addition of grass/spiced hops add an outstandingly fine balance. An excellent quaffer in which one bomber exceeds in its bounty and more then one is definately required and/or suitably easy to handle. Damn fine stuff!

Golden color with large white head. Bready malt aroma, honey, lightly fruity, with a touch of earthy hops. The flavor is outstanding, perfectly balanced, chewy bready malts with just enough sweetness. Quite simply, an absolutely delicious Helles.

Poured an effervescent amber with a large frothy off-white head.  Clean aroma of corn and piney hops.  Taste is clean and crisp, with pale malts and hops well balanced with a touch of toffee.  Very little aftertaste.  Very refreshing on this hot and muggy summer day.

Bomber.  Pours slightly hazy gold with a large, fluffy head.  Light aroma of grassy hops, sweet malts and sourdough.  The sourdough is the first thing to greet your tongue, followed by some a little bits of hops and caramel.  As it warms, it gets a little sweeter, but the sourness is always there.  Maybe if they sold this in 12oz bottles, instead of bombers, Id be more inclined to buy more, but this style doesnt seem to merit 22 oz.
Pours gold with a large lasting white head.  Smells of cereal, caramel with some mellow lemony tinges present.  Taste is on the sweeter side with oranges and apples at the forefront.  Weak mouthfeel.

Large white head, good retention and a fair lace. Clear gold color. Grainy malty nose with lightly floral hops. Med/light body. Bready malt flavors, lightly doughy, a touch of honey and a soft grainyness. Finish is clean and malty. Thanks SwedeDog!

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2005 Cask condition @ NERAX. Good nose, toasty. Lemon, sourdough, grass, toffee, hints of caramel. Hazy brownish orange color. No head. Sweet bitter flavors, same as aromas, starts with the grass, sourdough and goes to the caramel. Thin body, lite sticky mouthfeel, smooth citrus finish. Easy drinking. I like that Mr Davis brought a Helles to a cask fest.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: bomber courtesy my Brother.  Slightly hazy amber pour with a nice generous fluffy white head.  Malty nose, caramel also.  Sweet caramelly, refreshing.  Definately not cloying, but a nice level of sweetness.  Heavy maltiness, well balanced.  This is a nice brew.

This proves that the brewery not only produces awesome big beers, but can handle more subtle styles as well. Pours a dark golden/amber, with a massive head that leaves good lacing. Aroma is sweet munich malt, caramel, and light grassy hops. Mouthfeel is remarkably smooth, feels great on the palate. Starts off sweet with fruity notes of tart apples, mixed with sweet honey and some munich graininess. Turns pleasantly bitter with grassy and lightly spicy hop notes, and finishes crisp and a bit dry. Very well made, glad to have been able to try it.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2005 2004 bottle (possibly even 2003?) compliments (big compliments) to Jay (springslicker) who definitely sent me much better beers than I sent him in our last trade.  I owe you, man.  Good clear golden-deep yellow pour.  Medium amount of white head.  Aroma is faint and has notes of almonds, herbs, some lightly cardboardy notes, and some lightly spicy lager yeast.  The first whiff of vapor out of the bottle is great though, rich hay, soily hops and sweet malt.  Flavor of good grainy malt sweetness, nice and light but still present.  Waxing sweet on the finish, but then, there is some awkward alcohol persistency.  Hmm thats odd.  Drinking through it, it dosent seem to really bother me.  Good enough medium-light body.  Could use more hops, though Im impressed they didnt try to do the American thing and go crazy.  Quite filtered unfortunately, but to be expected and understood.   Carbonation seems restrained, which is great, as well there is a touch of lager yeast.  I dont know, I think this is closer to a pale lager than a dortmunder, as there is little hops apparency.  I dont want bitterness, but it needs more hallertauer and tettnang flavor.  Could use more body.On draught at Redbones, 2005 edition.  Wow, much better than in the bottle, not surprisingly.  Fresh, hoppy nose and crisp lager yeast, with light spiciness and some grainy malts sticking through.  Flavor is light honey and vanilla, bits of lemon and pale grains with a restrained, but flavorful hoppiness, all in quite a nice balance.  Refreshingly light bodied, but not watery or thin in the least.  Fantastic on draught as a summer quencher.  WIll have to try the new bottles again.  I see were back to Dortmunder/Helles on this and not Pale Lager.  Pretty good helles/pale lager, whatever the case.

clear, bright golden hue, massive slab of snow-white foam, swiftly dwindling down...aroma is slightly sweet, but balanced and dry, ultimately, lightly hoppy, floral, herbal, nice.
Taste: smooth, effortless, slick and wet, small texture, but altogether satisfactory. Small hoppy edge, adequate malt, ample taste, but perfectly drinkable. Light bodied, but not skinny in the flavor department, nor is it in any way outward or lush, no, its just right...and Im liking it more, as I finish it off!...slightly buttery-sweet, though, but Im not knocking that...
I can easily see this as the good beer you can serve to your friends who normally choose a macro lager or some such, theyll either be impressed by the total package and wowed by the taste, or wont know the difference.
Havent had a bad Hooker yet, and this continues that trend!

First off, I dont like this being categorized with Budweiser, Coors and Miller. I would rather it be categorized as a Helles as the brewer prefers... Anyhow... Crystal clear, textbook amber lager with a mid-sized, frothy, white head. Very good retention with spotty lacing. Interesting, malty and yeasty aroma. The nose is a blend of white pepper, jalapeno pepper (without the heat), a fusion of rye and white breads and damp straw. The flavor is hearty and malty, but very well balanced with just a hint of caramel and jalapeno (without the heat). Medium to full-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Lengthy, clean finish.

A huge creamy head formed while pouring this bomber of amber colored lager.
The aroma was yeasty and malty with very little to no hop aroma.
The flavor was sweet malt and has just enough hop bitterness hideing in there to balance this out nicely.
Smooth, clean finish.

This bomber came to me courtesy of BeerAdvocate spritdeus via a trade.  After poring, the beer revealed a clear golden colored body, and a two inch tall foamy off white head.  The aroma was clean with honey like pilsner malt, and faint florally grassy hops.  The taste was malt driven, with a sweet honeysuckle flavor and very mild hop bitterness.  The mouthfeel was creamy and soothing with a medium thick body.  This style is supposed to be difficult to pull off as there is no way to hide any off flavors.  And Troutbook is clearly at the top of their game, as they have brewed a beer that does not possess any off flavors that would need hiding.

NIce deed golden color (almost copper) with a big foamy egg shell hued head.  Grainy nose with hints of lemon.  Subtle caramel sweetness with a nice lemon hop bight in the finish.  Very refreshing.  Well balanced with a clean finish.  Nice beer.  Thanks to boto for this bomber bottle.

Bottle.  Sweet, grassy, doughy notes with a hint of yeast in the nose.  Transparent honey gold color with a long-standing frothy off-white head.  Bam.  Nice roastiness hits your right off the bat.  This smooths out into a very pleasant and enjoyable doughy middle.  Finishes with a nice hop kick at the end.  Great mouthfeel and is a very clean beer.  Technically great.  I wish it had a little more aroma.  Still a great beer for a style I dont typically enjoy.

Draught: This one pours a clear, somewhat darker golden color. There was a bit of a white head to it, which lingered a little while. The aroma is very malty, but not overly sweet. Some hint of hops and floral notes in the background. The taste is very crisp and clean. Somewhat less than medium bodied. A good malt flavor, with some sweetness and a hint of hops. Makes you wonder why the big 3 cant make a lager this tasty.
